name: The Magician
meaningUp: Manifestation, skill, resourcefulness, power, inspired action. The conscious use of will to transform thought into reality. All tools and resources are at hand; the universe conspires to support your intentions. Mastery over the elements of life, communication between higher and lower realms. Divine creativity channeled through human agency. Confidence backed by competence.
meaningRev: Manipulation, trickery, misused talent, or genuine skill thwarted by self-doubt. Power without purpose, or purpose without power. Resources present but not utilized. Communication blocked or used to deceive. Creative energy scattered or turned toward destructive ends. Confidence becomes arrogance, or competence undermined by imposter syndrome. The magician's tools present but wisdom absent.
description: A youthful figure in the robe of a magician, having the countenance of divine Apollo, with smile of confidence and shining eyes. Above his head is the mysterious sign of the Holy Spirit, the sign of life, like an endless cord, forming the figure 8 in a horizontal position . About his waist is a serpent-cincture, the serpent appearing to devour its own tail. This is familiar to most as a conventional symbol of eternity, but here it indicates more especially the eternity of attainment in the spirit. In the Magician's right hand is a wand raised towards heaven, while the left hand is pointing to the earth. This dual sign is known in very high grades of the Instituted Mysteries; it shews the descriptionent of grace, virtue and light, drawn from things above and derived to things below. The suggestion throughout is therefore the possession and communication of the Powers and Gifts of the Spirit. On the table in front of the Magician are the symbols of the four Tarot suits, signifying the elements of natural life, which lie like counters before the adept, and he adapts them as he wills. Beneath are roses and lilies, the flos campi and lilium convallium, changed into garden flowers, to shew the culture of aspiration. This card signifies the divine motive in man, reflecting God, the will in the liberation of its union with that which is above. It is also the unity of individual being on all planes, and in a very high sense it is thought, in the fixation thereof. With further reference to what I have called the sign of life and its connexion with the number 8, it may be remembered that Christian Gnosticism speaks of rebirth in Christ as a change "unto the Ogdoad." The mystic number is termed Jerusalem above, the Land flowing with Milk and Honey, the Holy Spirit and the Land of the Lord. According to Martinism, 8 is the number of Christ.

name: The High Priestess
meaningUp: Intuition, sacred knowledge, the subconscious, mystery. The keeper of hidden wisdom and the guardian between conscious and unconscious realms. Trust in inner knowing over external noise. The mysteries yet unrevealed, the path of the spiritual seeker. Divine feminine wisdom, reflection of the supernal. She who reads the hidden law and speaks its meaning to the worthy.
meaningRev: Intuition ignored or drowned out by mental chatter. Secrets becoming manipulation or paranoia. Hidden knowledge withheld where it should be shared, or sacred mysteries profaned through premature revelation. The inner voice thwarted by external demands. Spiritual connection blocked by materialism. Wisdom becoming mere intellectualism, mystery becoming confusion. The veil drawn too tightly or torn away too roughly.
description:
She has the lunar crescent at her feet, a horned diadem on her head, with a globe in the middle place, and a large solar cross on her breast. The scroll in her hands is inscribed with the word Tora, signifying the Greater Law, the Secret Law and the second sense of the Word. It is partly covered by her mantle, to shew that some things are implied and some spoken. She is seated between the white and black pillars--J. and B.--of the mystic Temple, and the veil of the Temple is behind her: it is embroidered with palms and pomegranates. The vestments are flowing and gauzy, and the mantle suggests light--a shimmering radiance. She has been called occult Science on the threshold of the Sanctuary of Isis, but she is really the Secret Church, the House which is of God and man. She represents also the Second Marriage of the Prince who is no longer of this world; she is the spiritual Bride and Mother, the daughter of the stars and the Higher Garden of Eden. She is, in fine, the Queen of the borrowed light, but this is the light of all. She is the Moon nourished by the milk of the Supernal Mother.
In a manner, she is also the Supernal Mother herself--that is to say, she is the bright reflection. It is in this sense of reflection that her truest and highest name in bolism is Shekinah--the co-habiting glory. According to Kabalism, there is a Shekinah both above and below. In the superior world it is called Binah, the Supernal Understanding which reflects to the emanations that are beneath. In the lower world it is MaIkuth--that world being, for this purpose, understood as a blessed Kingdom that with which it is made blessed being the Indwelling Glory. Mystically speaking, the Shekinah is the Spiritual Bride of the just man, and when he reads the Law she gives the Divine meaning. There are some respects in which this card is the highest and holiest of the Greater Arcana.

name: The Empress
meaningUp: Abundance, fertility, nurturing, creativity manifested. The Earth Mother in her fullness, all that grows and flourishes. Sensory beauty, material comfort, nature's generosity. Creation through love and attention. The harvest of what has been carefully tended. Gateway into life, embodiment of universal fecundity. Feminine power in its life-giving aspect.
meaningRev: Abundance thwarted by scarcity, or abundance becoming suffocating excess. Creativity blocked, fertility issues, or nurturing that smothers. Natural growth stunted or running wild without structure. Material comfort turning to materialism. The generous heart exploited or the abundant flow dammed up. Beauty that becomes vanity, care that becomes control. The garden untended or over-cultivated to sterility.
description:
A stately figure, seated, having rich vestments and royal aspect, as of a daughter of heaven and earth. Her diadem is of twelve stars, gathered in a cluster. The symbol of Venus is on the shield which rests near her. A field of corn is ripening in front of her, and beyond there is a fall of water. The sceptre which she bears is surmounted by the globe of this world. She is the inferior Garden of Eden, the Earthly Paradise, all that is symbolized by the visible house of man. She is not Regina coeli, but she is still refugium peccatorum, the fruitful mother of thousands. There are also certain aspects in which she has been correctly descriptionribed as desire and the wings thereof, as the woman clothed with the sun, as Gloria Mundi and the veil of the Sanctum Sanctorum; but she is not, I may add, the soul that has attained wings, unless all the symbolism is counted up another and unusual way. She is above all things universal fecundity and the outer sense of the Word. This is obvious, because there is no direct message which has been given to man like that which is borne by woman; but she does not herself carry its interpretation.
In another order of ideas, the card of the Empress signifies the door or gate by which an entrance is obtained into this life, as into the Garden of Venus; and then the way which leads out therefrom, into that which is beyond, is the secret known to the High Priestess: it is communicated by her to the elect. Most old attributions of this card are completely wrong on the symbolism--as, for example, its identification with the Word, Divine Nature, the Triad, and so forth.

name: The Emperor
meaningUp: Authority, structure, stability, leadership. The masculine principle of order and governance. Power exercised with wisdom, strength tempered by responsibility. Building lasting foundations, establishing law and boundaries. Protection and provision. The throne earned through achievement and maintained through just rule. Executive force in service of the greater good.
meaningRev: Authority misused or legitimate authority undermined. Structure becoming rigidity, stability turning to stagnation. Leadership thwarted by weak will or corrupted by tyranny. Power without compassion, control becoming domination. Boundaries that imprison rather than protect. The throne usurped or abandoned. Father figure absent or oppressive. Order collapsing into chaos or calcifying into inflexibility.
description:
He has a form of the Crux ansata for his sceptre and a globe in his left hand. He is a crowned monarch--commanding, stately, seated on a throne, the arms of which axe fronted by rams' heads. He is executive and realization, the power of this world, here clothed with the highest of its natural attributes. He is occasionally represented as seated on a cubic stone, which, however, confuses some of the issues. He is the virile power, to which the Empress responds, and in this sense is he who seeks to remove the Veil of Isis; yet she remains virgo intacta.
It should be understood that this card and that of the Empress do not precisely represent the condition of married life, though this state is implied. On the surface, as I have indicated, they stand for mundane royalty, uplifted on the seats of the mighty; but above this there is the suggestion of another presence. They signify also--and the male figure especially--the higher kingship, occupying the intellectual throne. Hereof is the lordship of thought rather than of the animal world. Both personalities, after their own manner, are "full of strange experience," but theirs is not consciously the wisdom which draws from a higher world. The Emperor has been descriptionribed as (a) will in its embodied form, but this is only one of its applications, and (b) as an expression of virtualities contained in the Absolute Being--but this is fantasy.

name: The Hierophant
meaningUp: Tradition, spiritual authority, conventional wisdom, education, conformity to social structures. The bridge between divine and human understanding through established teachings. Guidance from mentors and institutions. Shared values that bind communities. Sacred knowledge transmitted through proper channels. Marriage of spiritual and worldly concerns within traditional frameworks.
meaningRev: Tradition stifling growth or spiritual seeking thwarted by rigid doctrine. Rebellion against authority, or authority grown corrupt and self-serving. Wisdom of elders ignored or false prophets followed. Teaching that indoctrinates rather than illuminates. Convention becoming oppression, or necessary structure rejected in blind rebellion. The channel of grace clogged by bureaucracy and empty ritual.
description:
He wears the triple crown and is seated between two pillars, but they are not those of the Temple which is guarded by the High Priestess. In his left hand he holds a sceptre terminating in the triple cross, and with his right hand he gives the well-known ecclesiastical sign which is called that of esotericism, distinguishing between the manifest and concealed part of doctrine. It is noticeable in this connexion that the High Priestess makes no sign. At his feet are the crossed keys, and two priestly ministers in albs kneel before him. He has been usually called the Pope, which is a particular application of the more general office that he symbolizes. He is the ruling power of external religion, as the High Priestess is the prevailing genius of the esoteric, withdrawn power. The proper meanings of this card have suffered woeful admixture from nearly all hands. Grand Orient says truly that the Hierophant is the power of the keys, exoteric orthodox doctrine, and the outer side of the life which leads to the doctrine; but he is certainly not the prince of occult doctrine, as another commentator has suggested.
He is rather the summa totius theologiæ, when it has passed into the utmost rigidity of expression; but he symbolizes also all things that are righteous and sacred on the manifest side. As such, he is the channel of grace belonging to the world of institution as distinct from that of Nature, and he is the leader of salvation for the human race at large. He is the order and the head of the recognized hierarchy, which is the reflection of another and greater hierarchic order; but it may so happen that the pontiff forgets the significance of this his symbolic state and acts as if he contained within his proper measures all that his sign signifies or his symbol seeks to shew forth. He is not, as it has been thought, philosophy-except on the theological side; he is not inspiration; and he is not religion, although he is a mode of its expression.

name: The Lovers
meaningUp: Love, union, harmony, choices with moral weight. The sacred partnership, attraction on all levels. Divine and human love intertwined. Alignment of values, authentic connection. The choice between higher and lower impulses, integration of opposites. Beauty recognized and innocence preserved even in knowledge. Relationship as spiritual practice and path of completion.
meaningRev: Love thwarted by circumstance or corrupted by desire alone. Disharmony in partnership, values misaligned. Poor choices in relationships or moral compromise. Attraction without connection, or connection sabotaged by fear. The sacred union profaned or idealized partnership revealing itself as flawed. Temptation leading astray, or authentic desire thwarted by duty. Discord where harmony should reign.
description:
The sun shines in the zenith, and beneath is a great winged figure with arms extended, pouring down influences. In the foreground are two human figures, male and female, unveiled before each other, as if Adam and Eve when they first occupied the paradise of the earthly body. Behind the man is the Tree of Life, bearing twelve fruits, and the Tree of the Knowledge of Good and Evil is behind the woman; the serpent is twining round it. The figures suggest youth, virginity, innocence and love before it is contaminated by gross material desire. This is in all simplicity the card of human love, here exhibited as part of the way, the truth and the life. It replaces, by recourse to first principles, the old card of marriage, which I have descriptionribed previously, and the later follies which depicted man between vice and virtue. In a very high sense, the card is a mystery of the Covenant and Sabbath.
The suggestion in respect of the woman is that she signifies that attraction towards the sensitive life which carries within it the idea of the Fall of Man, but she is rather the working of a Secret Law of Providence than a willing and conscious temptress. It is through her imputed lapse that man shall arise ultimately, and only by her can he complete himself. The card is therefore in its way another intimation concerning the great mystery of womanhood. The old meanings fall to pieces of necessity with the old pictures, but even as interpretations of the latter, some of them were of the order of commonplace and others were false in symbolism.

name: The Chariot
meaningUp: Victory, determination, willpower, control. Triumph through discipline and focus. Opposing forces harnessed and directed toward a single purpose. Movement forward despite obstacles. The warrior's journey, conquest of the external world and the internal landscape. Mastery earned through effort. Success in ventures requiring courage and sustained will.
meaningRev: Victory thwarted by loss of control or control becoming oppressive force. Will scattered in multiple directions achieving nothing. Movement blocked or progress made in wrong direction. Triumph that proves hollow or costs too much. Forces pulling in opposition without resolution. Defeat snatched from the jaws of victory. Aggression without purpose, ambition without ethics. The chariot overturned or the charioteer fallen.
description:
An erect and princely figure carrying a drawn sword and corresponding, broadly speaking, to the traditional descriptionription which I have given in the first part. On the shoulders of the victorious hero are supposed to be the Urim and Thummim. He has led captivity captive; he is conquest on all planes--in the mind, in science, in progress, in certain trials of initiation. He has thus replied to the sphinx, and it is on this account that I have accepted the variation of Éliphas Lévi; two sphinxes thus draw his chariot. He is above all things triumph in the mind.
It is to be understood for this reason (a) that the question of the sphinx is concerned with a Mystery of Nature and not of the world of Grace, to which the charioteer could offer no answer; (b) that the planes of his conquest are manifest or external and not within himself; (c) that the liberation which he effects may leave himself in the bondage of the logical understanding; (d) that the tests of initiation through which he has passed in triumph are to be understood physically or rationally; and (e) that if he came to the pillars of that Temple between which the High Priestess is seated, he could not open the scroll called Tora, nor if she questioned him could he answer. He is not hereditary royalty and he is not priesthood.

name: Fortitude
meaningUp: Inner strength, courage, compassion, gentle influence over force. The power of the calm heart, mastery through love rather than domination. Patience that outlasts violence, quiet confidence that needs no display. The higher nature taming the passionate nature not through suppression but integration. Moral courage, endurance, the strength found in divine alignment.
meaningRev: Strength thwarted by doubt or misused as brutality. Courage failing at crucial moments, or false courage becoming recklessness. Gentle influence turning to weakness and exploitation. The lion unleashed in destructive rage or the spirit crushed by external force. Self-doubt undermining genuine power. Patience becoming passivity, or passion overwhelming wisdom. Raw force where subtle influence was needed.
description:
A woman, over whose head there broods the same symbol of life which we have seen in the card of the Magician, is closing the jaws of a lion. The only point in which this design differs from the conventional presentations is that her beneficent fortitude has already subdued the lion, which is being led by a chain of flowers. For reasons which satisfy myself, this card has been interchanged with that of justice, which is usually numbered eight. As the variation carries nothing with it which will signify to the reader, there is no cause for explanation. Fortitude, in one of its most exalted aspects, is connected with the Divine Mystery of Union; the virtue, of course, operates in all planes, and hence draws on all in its symbolism. It connects also with innocentia inviolata, and with the strength which resides in contemplation.
These higher meanings are, however, matters of inference, and I do not suggest that they are transparent on the surface of the card. They are intimated in a concealed manner by the chain of flowers, which signifies, among many other things, the sweet yoke and the light burden of Divine Law, when it has been taken into the heart of hearts. The card has nothing to do with self-confidence in the ordinary sense, though this has been suggested--but it concerns the confidence of those whose strength is God, who have found their refuge in Him. There is one aspect in which the lion signifies the passions, and she who is called Strength is the higher nature in its liberation. It has walked upon the asp and the basilisk and has trodden down the lion and the dragon.

name: The Hermit
meaningUp: Inner guidance, solitude, wisdom through introspection, soul-searching. The light within that illuminates the path. Withdrawal from the noise of the world to hear the divine whisper. Teaching through example rather than proclamation. The seeker who has found and now guides others. Patience, contemplation, the wisdom earned through experience and reflection.
meaningRev: Isolation thwarting growth or sought wisdom remaining elusive. Loneliness masquerading as solitude, withdrawal becoming escapism. Inner guidance ignored or false light followed. The wise teacher becoming the isolated hermit. Paranoia and suspicion replacing healthy boundaries. The lamp hidden when it should illuminate others, or the seeker lost in endless searching without finding. Wisdom hoarded rather than shared.
description:
The variation from the conventional models in this card is only that the lamp is not enveloped partially in the mantle of its bearer, who blends the idea of the Ancient of Days with the Light of the World It is a star which shines in the lantern. I have said that this is a card of attainment, and to extend this conception the figure is seen holding up his beacon on an eminence. Therefore the Hermit is not, as Court de Gebelin explained, a wise man in search of truth and justice; nor is he, as a later explanation proposes, an especial example of experience. His beacon intimates that "where I am, you also may be."
It is further a card which is understood quite incorrectly when it is connected with the idea of occult isolation, as the protection of personal magnetism against admixture. This is one of the frivolous renderings which we owe to Éliphas Lévi. It has been adopted by the French Order of Martinism and some of us have heard a great deal of the Silent and Unknown Philosophy enveloped by his mantle from the knowledge of the profane. In true Martinism, the significance of the term Philosophe inconnu was of another order. It did not refer to the intended concealment of the Instituted Mysteries, much less of their substitutes, but--like the card itself--to the truth that the Divine Mysteries secure their own protection from those who are unprepared.

name: Wheel Of Fortune
meaningUp: Destiny, cycles, turning points, fortune changing. The great wheel of life in motion, what rises must fall and what falls shall rise again. Providence working through apparent chance. Breakthrough moments, karma ripening, the unexpected arrival of change. Understanding that nothing remains static, adaptation to life's natural rhythms. Good fortune, expansion, the ascending arc of the cycle.
meaningRev: Fortune turning unfavorable, or good fortune thwarted by clinging to the moment. Cycles disrupted or repeating destructively. Destiny resisted leading to greater struggle. The descending arc of the wheel, contraction and limitation. Bad timing, opportunities missed. The wheel stuck or spinning out of control. Karma arriving in difficult form. Change itself becoming the source of instability rather than growth.
description:
In this symbol I have again followed the reconstruction of Éliphas Lévi, who has furnished several variants. It is legitimate--as I have intimated--to use Egyptian symbolism when this serves our purpose, provided that no theory of origin is implied therein. I have, however, presented Typhon in his serpent form. The symbolism is, of course, not exclusively Egyptian, as the four Living Creatures of Ezekiel occupy the angles of the card, and the wheel itself follows other indications of Lévi in respect of Ezekiel's vision, as illustrative of the particular Tarot Key. With the French occultist, and in the design itself, the symbolic picture stands for the perpetual motion of a fluidic universe and for the flux of human life. The Sphinx is the equilibrium therein. The transliteration of Taro as Rota is inscribed on the wheel, counterchanged with the letters of the Divine Name--to shew that Providence is imphed through all. But this is the Divine intention within, and the similar intention without is exemplified by the four Living Creatures. Sometimes the sphinx is represented couchant on a pedestal above, which defrauds the symbolism by stultifying the essential idea of stability amidst movement.
Behind the general notion expressed in the symbol there lies the denial of chance and the fatality which is implied therein. It may be added that, from the days of Lévi onward, the occult explanations of this card are--even for occultism itself--of a singularly fatuous kind. It has been said to mean principle, fecundity, virile honour, ruling authority, etc. The findings of common fortune-telling are better than this on their own plane.

name: Justice
meaningUp: Fairness, truth, cause and effect, accountability. The scales balanced, each receiving their due. Legal matters resolved equitably. Truth revealed and honored. Consequences aligned with actions. Integrity rewarded, dishonesty exposed. The moral order of the universe manifesting in material realm. Decisions made on principles rather than passions.
meaningRev: Justice thwarted by corruption or bias, or justice itself becoming cold and merciless. Truth obscured, legal complications, unfair outcomes. The scales tipped by prejudice or power. Accountability avoided or punishment exceeding the crime. Integrity punished, dishonesty rewarded. Karmic debt delayed or compounded. Decisions made on appearances rather than truth. The law perverted from its purpose.
description:
As this card follows the traditional symbolism and carries above all its obvious meanings, there is little to say regarding it outside the few considerations collected in the first part, to which the reader is referred.
It will be seen, however, that the figure is seated between pillars, like the High Priestess, and on this account it seems desirable to indicate that the moral principle which deals unto every man according to his works--while, of course, it is in strict analogy with higher things;--differs in its essence from the spiritual justice which is involved in the idea of election. The latter belongs to a mysterious order of Providence, in virtue of which it is possible for certain men to conceive the idea of dedication to the highest things. The operation of this is like the breathing of the Spirit where it wills, and we have no canon of criticism or ground of explanation concerning it. It is analogous to the possession of the fairy gifts and the high gifts and the gracious gifts of the poet: we have them or have not, and their presence is as much a mystery as their absence. The law of Justice is not however involved by either alternative. In conclusion, the pillars of Justice open into one world and the pillars of the High Priestess into another.

name: The Hanged Man
meaningUp: Surrender, new perspective, suspension, sacrifice leading to wisdom. The pause that changes everything. Letting go to receive more. Seeing from an inverted viewpoint that reveals hidden truth. Willing sacrifice for greater purpose. The mystic death while still in life. Patience in suspension, trust in timing. The martyr whose sacrifice is not suffering but transformation.
meaningRev: Sacrifice without meaning, or necessary surrender thwarted by ego. Perspective shift available but refused. Stuck in limbo without the wisdom it should bring. Martyrdom becoming victimhood. Patience turning to stagnation. The suspension that should be temporary becoming permanent. False sacrifice that serves no purpose. Release resisted at great cost. The upside-down world offering insight but the eyes remain blind.
description:
The gallows from which he is suspended forms a Tau cross, while the figure--from the position of the legs--forms a fylfot cross. There is a nimbus about the head of the seeming martyr. It should be noted (1) that the tree of sacrifice is living wood, with leaves thereon; (2) that the face expresses deep entrancement, not suffering; (3) that the figure, as a whole, suggests life in suspension, but life and not death. It is a card of profound significance, but all the significance is veiled. One of his editors suggests that Éliphas Lévi did not know the meaning, which is unquestionable nor did the editor himself. It has been called falsely a card of martyrdom, a card a of prudence, a card of the Great Work, a card of duty; but we may exhaust all published interpretations and find only vanity. I will say very simply on my own part that it expresses the relation, in one of its aspects, between the Divine and the Universe.
He who can understand that the story of his higher nature is imbedded in this symbolism will receive intimations concerning a great awakening that is possible, and will know that after the sacred Mystery of Death there is a glorious Mystery of Resurrection.

name: Death
meaningUp: Transformation, endings, transition, release. The necessary death that precedes rebirth. Structures dissolving to make way for new forms. The great letting go, acceptance of impermanence. Not literal death but metamorphosis. The old self dying so the new self can emerge. Natural cycles of decay and renewal. The horseman that levels all, opening the path to what comes next.
meaningRev: Transformation resisted leading to stagnation, or change that destroys without renewal. Endings prolonged unnecessarily, clinging to what should be released. Fear of letting go preventing growth. Death becoming mere destruction without the promise of rebirth. The necessary ending thwarted, decay without renewal. Stuck in the in-between state, neither fully dead nor alive. Change forced before its time or avoided past its time.
description:
The veil or mask of life is perpetuated in change, transformation and passage from lower to higher, and this is more fitly represented in the rectified Tarot by one of the apocalyptic visions than by the crude notion of the reaping skeleton. Behind it lies the whole world of ascent in the spirit. The mysterious horseman moves slowly, bearing a black banner emblazoned with the Mystic Rose, which signifies life. Between two pillars on the verge of the horizon there shines the sun of immortality. The horseman carries no visible weapon, but king and child and maiden fall before him, while a prelate with clasped hands awaits his end.
There should be no need to point out that the suggestion of death which I have made in connection with the previous card is, of course, to be understood mystically, but this is not the case in the present instance. The natural transit of man to the next stage of his being either is or may be one form of his progress, but the exotic and almost unknown entrance, while still in this life, into the state of mystical death is a change in the form of consciousness and the passage into a state to which ordinary death is neither the path nor gate. The existing occult explanations of the 13th card are, on the whole, better than usual, rebirth, creation, destination, renewal, and the rest.

name: Temperance
meaningUp: Balance, moderation, harmony, alchemy. The middle path, integration of opposites. Patience and careful mixing that creates something greater than its parts. Healing through equilibrium. The angel blending celestial and earthly. Time as ally, gradual progress. Higher consciousness tempering material nature. Purpose found in synthesis rather than extremes.
meaningRev: Balance thwarted by excess or deficiency, or harmony itself becoming bland compromise. Impatience disrupting the alchemical process. Opposing forces failing to integrate. Extremes chosen over moderation. Healing blocked or the medicine itself causing harm. The delicate balance tipped into chaos. Gradual progress abandoned for quick fixes. The blending that should create beauty producing only muddle.
description:
A winged angel, with the sign of the sun upon his forehead and on his breast the square and triangle of the septenary. I speak of him in the masculine sense, but the figure is neither male nor female. It is held to be pouring the essences of life from chalice to chalice. It has one foot upon the earth and one upon waters, thus illustrating the nature of the essences. A direct path goes up to certain heights on the verge of the horizon, and above there is a great light, through which a crown is seen vaguely. Hereof is some part of the Secret of Eternal Life, as it is possible to man in his incarnation. All the conventional emblems are renounced herein.
So also are the conventional meanings, which refer to changes in the seasons, perpetual movement of life and even the combination of ideas. It is, moreover, untrue to say that the figure symbolizes the genius of the sun, though it is the analogy of solar light, realized in the third part of our human triplicity. It is called Temperance fantastically, because, when the rule of it obtains in our consciousness, it tempers, combines and harmonises the psychic and material natures. Under that rule we know in our rational part something of whence we came and whither we are going.

name: The Devil
meaningUp: Bondage, materialism, addiction, shadow self. The chains we forge ourselves, often through pleasure-seeking. Temptation, unhealthy attachments, toxic patterns. The lie that we are not free, when the chains are loose. Material world mistaken for ultimate reality. Power of the base instincts when unconscious. The threshold keeper that must be faced and understood, not destroyed.
meaningRev: Bondage recognized and broken, or freedom thwarted by fear of the unknown. Addictions confronted or spiraling deeper. The chains loosening or tightening further. Shadow work begun or shadow completely denied. Material attachments released or clutched more desperately. False freedom that's still bondage in disguise. Liberation from one trap only to fall into another. The devil known and losing power, or unknown and thus gaining power.
description:
The design is an accommodation, mean or harmony, between several motives mentioned in the first part. The Horned Goat of Mendes, with wings like those of a bat, is standing on an altar. At the pit of the stomach there is the sign of Mercury. The right hand is upraised and extended, being the reverse of that benediction which is given by the Hierophant in the fifth card. In the left hand there is a great flaming torch, inverted towards the earth. A reversed pentagram is on the forehead. There is a ring in front of the altar, from which two chains are carried to the necks of two figures, male and female. These are analogous with those of the fifth card, as if Adam and Eve after the Fall. Hereof is the chain and fatality of the material life.
The figures are tailed, to signify the animal nature, but there is human intelligence in the faces, and he who is exalted above them is not to be their master for ever. Even now, he is also a bondsman, sustained by the evil that is in him and blind to the liberty of service. With more than his usual derision for the arts which he pretended to respect and interpret as a master therein, Éliphas Lévi affirms that the Baphometic figure is occult science and magic. Another commentator says that in the Divine world it signifies predestination, but there is no correspondence in that world with the things which below are of the brute. What it does signify is the Dweller on the Threshold without the Mystical Garden when those are driven forth therefrom who have eaten the forbidden fruit.

name: The Tower
meaningUp: Sudden upheaval, revelation, destruction of false structures. The lightning strike of truth that shatters comfortable lies. Necessary catastrophe, the house built on sand falling. Ego death, liberation through destruction. The old order collapsing to make way for authentic foundation. Awakening that feels like disaster. The rending of illusion, however painful.
meaningRev: Catastrophe thwarted but lesson unlearned, or destruction without the clearing it should bring. False structures maintained through fear of collapse. Revelation avoided, truth suppressed. The tower standing but cracked and unstable. Change resisted until it becomes even more violent. Breakdown becoming permanent crisis rather than breakthrough. The necessary fall delayed, making it worse when it comes. Destruction that breaks without rebuilding.
description:
Occult explanations attached to this card are meagre and mostly disconcerting. It is idle to indicate that it depicts min in all its aspects, because it bears this evidence on the surface. It is said further that it contains the first allusion to a material building, but I do not conceive that the Tower is more or less material than the pillars which we have met with in three previous cases. I see nothing to warrant Papus in supposing that it is literally the fall of Adam, but there is more in favour of his alternative--that it signifies the materialization of the spiritual word. The bibliographer Christian imagines that it is the downfall of the mind, seeking to penetrate the mystery of God. I agree rather with Grand Orient that it is the ruin of the House of We, when evil has prevailed therein, and above all that it is the rending of a House of Doctrine. I understand that the reference is, however, to a House of Falsehood. It illustrates also in the most comprehensive way the old truth that "except the Lord build the house, they labour in vain that build it."
There is a sense in which the catastrophe is a reflection from the previous card, but not on the side of the symbolism which I have tried to indicate therein. It is more correctly a question of analogy; one is concerned with the fall into the material and animal state, while the other signifies destruction on the intellectual side. The Tower has been spoken of as the chastisement of pride and the intellect overwhelmed in the attempt to penetrate the Mystery of God; but in neither case do these explanations account for the two persons who are the living sufferers. The one is the literal word made void and the other its false interpretation. In yet a deeper sense, it may signify also the end of a dispensation, but there is no possibility here for the consideration of this involved question.

name: The Star
meaningUp: Hope, inspiration, renewal, spiritual connection. The light that guides through darkness. Healing waters freely given. Faith restored after crisis. The naked truth of being, unashamed and generous. Divine grace pouring into material realm. The wish that can come true, the prayer being answered. Beauty, serenity, the calm after storm promising new growth.
meaningRev: Hope thwarted by despair, or false hope leading astray. Inspiration drying up, spiritual connection lost. Healing disrupted or sought in wrong places. Faith shaken, trust betrayed. The generous flow withheld or poisoned. Wishes unfulfilled, prayers seemingly unheard. Beauty marred, serenity disturbed. The guiding star obscured by clouds of doubt. Grace offered but not received.
description:
A great, radiant star of eight rays, surrounded by seven lesser stars--also of eight rays. The female figure in the foreground is entirely naked. Her left knee is on the land and her right foot upon the water. She pours Water of Life from two great ewers, irrigating sea and land. Behind her is rising ground and on the right a shrub or tree, whereon a bird alights. The figure expresses eternal youth and beauty. The star is l'étoile flamboyante, which appears in Masonic symbolism, but has been confused therein. That which the figure communicates to the living scene is the substance of the heavens and the elements. It has been said truly that the mottoes of this card are "Waters of Life freely" and "Gifts of the Spirit."
The summary of several tawdry explanations says that it is a card of hope. On other planes it has been certified as immortality and interior light. For the majority of prepared minds, the figure will appear as the type of Truth unveiled, glorious in undying beauty, pouring on the waters of the soul some part and measure of her priceless possession. But she is in reality the Great Mother in the Kabalistic Sephira Binah, which is supernal Understanding, who communicates to the Sephiroth that are below in the measure that they can receive her influx.

name: The Moon
meaningUp: Illusion, intuition, the unconscious, anxiety, the unknown. The reflected light that guides but also deceives. Dreams, visions, psychic sensitivity. The realm of the imagination with all its fears and wonders. That which lurks beneath the surface. The path through uncertainty requiring trust in inner sight. Mysteries that confuse or enlighten. The animal nature stirring.
meaningRev: Illusion cleared or deepened into delusion. Intuition thwarted by mental noise or false intuition trusted. Anxiety mastered or spiraling into terror. The unconscious rising in destructive ways or its messages ignored. Deception revealed or lies believed. Imagination serving fear rather than creativity. The path through uncertainty becoming complete disorientation. Monsters from the deep breaching the surface.
description:
The distinction between this card and some of the conventional types is that the moon is increasing on what is called the side of mercy, to the right of the observer. It has sixteen chief and sixteen secondary rays. The card represents life of the imagination apart from life of the spirit. The path between the towers is the issue into the unknown. The dog and wolf are the fears of the natural mind in the presence of that place of exit, when there is only reflected light to guide it.
The last reference is a key to another form of symbolism. The intellectual light is a reflection and beyond it is the unknown mystery which it cannot shew forth. It illuminates our animal nature, types of which are represented below--the dog, the wolf and that which comes up out of the deeps, the nameless and hideous tendency which is lower than the savage beast. It strives to attain manifestation, symbolized by crawling from the abyss of water to the land, but as a rule it sinks back whence it came. The face of the mind directs a calm gaze upon the unrest below; the dew of thought falls; the message is: Peace, be still; and it may be that there shall come a calm upon the animal nature, while the abyss beneath shall cease from giving up a form.

name: The Sun
meaningUp: Joy, success, vitality, clarity, innocence restored. The direct light of consciousness illuminating all. Simple truth, childlike wonder, authentic happiness. Warmth and life-giving energy. Everything seen clearly in daylight. Achievements recognized and celebrated. The completion of a cycle in triumph. Eden regained, simplicity on the far side of complexity.
meaningRev: Joy thwarted by clouds, or brightness that blinds and burns. Success delayed or spoiled by its achievement. Vitality depleted, clarity giving way to confusion. Innocence lost or false innocence pretending trauma hasn't occurred. The light too harsh, exposing what should remain private. Happiness pursued becoming the obstacle to happiness. Simplicity becoming simplistic. The child in chains rather than dancing free.
description:
The naked child mounted on a white horse and displaying a red standard has been mentioned already as the better symbolism connected with this card. It is the destiny of the Supernatural East and the great and holy light which goes before the endless procession of humanity, coming out from the walled garden of the sensitive life and passing on the journey home. The card signifies, therefore, the transit from the manifest light of this world, represented by the glorious sun of earth, to the light of the world to come, which goes before aspiration and is typified by the heart of a child.
But the last allusion is again the key to a different form or aspect of the symbolism. The sun is that of consciousness in the spirit - the direct as the antithesis of the reflected light. The characteristic type of humanity has become a little child therein--a child in the sense of simplicity and innocence in the sense of wisdom. In that simplicity, he bears the seal of Nature and of Art; in that innocence, he signifies the restored world. When the self-knowing spirit has dawned in the consciousness above the natural mind, that mind in its renewal leads forth the animal nature in a state of perfect conformity.

name: The Last Judgment
meaningUp: Renewal, reckoning, awakening, absolution. The call from beyond that cannot be ignored. Rising to meet one's higher purpose. The past integrated and released. Judgments rendered fairly, debts settled. Resurrection into new life. The moment of clarity when everything makes sense. Transformation through evaluation and acceptance. Forgiveness, both given and received.
meaningRev: The call unheard or ignored, or judgment that condemns without offering redemption. Awakening thwarted by resistance to change. The past still binding the present. Unfair judgments, harsh sentences. Resurrection delayed, new life stillborn. Clarity clouded by guilt or denial. The summons to purpose refused. Forgiveness withheld or demanded where accountability is needed. Second chances squandered.
description:
I have said that this symbol is essentially invariable in all Tarot sets, or at least the variations do not alter its character. The great angel is here encompassed by clouds, but he blows his bannered trumpet, and the cross as usual is displayed on the banner. The dead are rising from their tombs--a woman on the right, a man on the left hand, and between them their child, whose back is turned. But in this card there are more than three who are restored, and it has been thought worth while to make this variation as illustrating the insufficiency of current explanations. It should be noted that all the figures are as one in the wonder, adoration and ecstacy expressed by their attitudes. It is the card which registers the accomplishment of the great work of transformation in answer to the summons of the Supernal--which summons is heard and answered from within.
Herein is the intimation of a significance which cannot well be carried further in the present place. What is that within us which does sound a trumpet and all that is lower in our nature rises in response--almost in a moment, almost in the twinkling of an eye? Let the card continue to depict, for those who can see no further, the Last judgment and the resurrection in the natural body; but let those who have inward eyes look and discover therewith. They will understand that it has been called truly in the past a card of eternal life, and for this reason it may be compared with that which passes under the name of Temperance.

name: The Fool
meaningUp: New beginnings, spontaneity, innocence, taking a leap of faith. The spirit in search of experience, unburdened by fear or expectation. Represents the freedom to start fresh, trust in the journey, and openness to possibility. Folly transformed into divine courage. The traveler setting forth without knowing the destination but trusting the path will appear.
meaningRev: Recklessness thwarted by consequence, or wisdom thwarted by foolish choices. Naivety leading to exploitation or poor judgment. Opportunities missed through hesitation or squandered through carelessness. The leap of faith becoming a dangerous fall. Freedom without direction becoming aimless wandering. Spontaneity corrupted into chaos or irresponsibility.
description:
With light step, as if earth and its trammels had little power to restrain him, a young man in gorgeous vestments pauses at the brink of a precipice among the great heights of the world; he surveys the blue distance before him-its expanse of sky rather than the prospect below. His act of eager walking is still indicated, though he is stationary at the given moment; his dog is still bounding. The edge which opens on the depth has no terror; it is as if angels were waiting to uphold him, if it came about that he leaped from the height. His countenance is full of intelligence and expectant dream. He has a rose in one hand and in the other a costly wand, from which depends over his right shoulder a wallet curiously embroidered. He is a prince of the other world on his travels through this one-all amidst the morning glory, in the keen air. The sun, which shines behind him, knows whence he came, whither he is going, and how he will return by another path after many days. He is the spirit in search of experience. Many symbols of the Instituted Mysteries are summarized in this card, which reverses, under high warrants, all the confusions that have preceded it.
In his Manual of Cartomancy, Grand Orient has a curious suggestion of the office of Mystic Fool, as apart of his process in higher divination; but it might call for more than ordinary gifts to put it into operation. We shall see how the card fares according to the common arts of fortune-telling, and it will be an example, to those who can discern, of the fact, otherwise so evident, that the Trumps Major had no place originally in the arts of psychic gambling, when cards are used as the counters and pretexts. Of the circumstances under which this art arose we know, however, very little. The conventional explanations say that the Fool signifies the flesh, the sensitive life, and by a peculiar satire its subsidiary name was at one time the alchemist, as depicting folly at the most insensate stage.

name: The World
meaningUp: Completion, achievement, integration, cosmic consciousness. The dance at the center of all. Everything coming together in perfect harmony. Success on all levels. The journey complete, wisdom earned. Fulfillment of potential. The self fully realized and the universe understood. Cosmic unity experienced. The crown of achievement, the end that is also a beginning.
meaningRev: Completion thwarted at the final step, or achievement that brings emptiness. Integration failing, the pieces remaining separate. Success on external level masking internal fragmentation. The journey incomplete, destination not reached. Fulfillment sought but not found. Unity experienced as loss of self rather than expansion. The laurel just beyond reach. The cycle stuck before its natural end, or rushed past without the wisdom it should impart.
description:
As this final message of the Major Trumps is unchanged--and indeed unchangeable--in respect of its design, it has been partly descriptionribed already regarding its deeper sense. It represents also the perfection and end of the Cosmos, the secret which is within it, the rapture of the universe when it understands itself in God. It is further the state of the soul in the consciousness of Divine Vision, reflected from the self-knowing spirit. But these meanings are without prejudice to that which I have said concerning it on the material side.
It has more than one message on the macrocosmic side and is, for example, the state of the restored world when the law of manifestation shall have been carried to the highest degree of natural perfection. But it is perhaps more especially a story of the past, referring to that day when all was declared to be good, when the morning stars sang together and all the Sons of God shouted for joy. One of the worst explanations concerning it is that the figure symbolizes the Magus when he has reached the highest degree of initiation; another account says that it represents the absolute, which is ridiculous. The figure has been said to stand for Truth, which is, however, more properly allocated to the seventeenth card. Lastly, it has been called the Crown of the Magi.

name: Page of Wands
meaningUp: Enthusiasm, exploration, discovery. Bearer of exciting news. Passionate beginner, eagerness meeting opportunity. Free spirit, adventurous nature. Loyal and bringing favorable messages. The spark of potential not yet fully manifested.
meaningRev: Enthusiasm thwarted becoming disappointment, or enthusiasm without substance. Bad news arriving. Passion without discipline, exploration without purpose. Unfavorable messages. The messenger proving unreliable. Potential squandered through immaturity or external obstacles preventing the young energy from expressing itself.
description: In a scene similar to the former, a young man stands in the act of proclamation. He is unknown but faithful, and his tidings are strange.

name: Knight of Wands
meaningUp: Action, adventure, impulsiveness, passion unleashed. The charge ahead fearlessly. Energy, enthusiasm, confidence. Movement and change. Hasty but brave. The crusader for his cause. Attraction and charm.
meaningRev: Action thwarted or becoming recklessness. Adventures turning to disasters. Impulsiveness causing harm. Passion without direction. The charge ending in defeat or retreat. Energy burned in waste. Confidence revealing itself as arrogance. Movement without purpose, change for change's sake. The crusader becoming the fanatic.
description: He is shewn as if upon a journey, armed with a short wand, and although mailed is not on a warlike errand. He is passing mounds or pyramids. The motion of the horse is a key to the character of its rider, and suggests the precipitate mood, or things connected therewith.

name: Queen of Wands
meaningUp: Confidence, determination, vivaciousness, magnetic personality. Independence, honoring one's own authority. Warm, generous, socially adept. Creative power in action. Passionate loyalty. The woman who commands respect and affection.
meaningRev: Confidence becoming domineering behavior, or confidence thwarted by insecurity. Independence becoming isolation. Warmth withdrawn or manipulated for control. Jealousy, deceit, infidelity. Generosity withheld or given with strings attached. The charismatic leader becoming the tyrant, or the natural leader prevented from leading.
description: The Wands throughout this suit are always in leaf, as it is a suit of life and animation. Emotionally and otherwise, the Queen's personality corresponds to that of the King, but is more magnetic.

name: King of Wands
meaningUp: Natural leadership, vision, honor, entrepreneurial spirit. Noble, honest, conscientious. Fatherly authority exercised wisely. Mature use of creative power. Inspiring others to action. Taking responsibility with confidence.
meaningRev: Leadership corrupted or thwarted, vision blinded by ego. Honesty compromised. Authority misused or undermined. Entrepreneurial spirit becoming exploitation. The father figure absent or tyrannical. Inspiring others toward wrong ends, or good influence blocked by others' malice. Power without wisdom.
description: The physical and emotional nature to which this card is attributed is dark, ardent, lithe, animated, impassioned, noble. The King uplifts a flowering wand, and wears, like his three correspondences in the remaining suits, what is called a cap of maintenance beneath his crown. He connects with the symbol of the lion, which is emblazoned on the back of his throne.

name: Ace of Wands
meaningUp: Pure creative potential, inspiration, new beginning in creative or spiritual venture. The spark of divine fire descending. Initiative, passion, invention, enterprise. The seed of action waiting to sprout. Virility, life force, the power to begin. Opportunity presenting itself clearly.
meaningRev: Creative energy blocked or misdirected. False starts, inspiration that doesn't translate to action. The spark failing to catch fire. Initiative thwarted by fear or external obstacles. Projects begun but not sustained. Potential recognized but not seized. Sexual or creative impotence.
description: A hand issuing from a cloud grasps a stout wand or club.

name: Two of Wands
meaningUp: Planning, progress, decisions about direction. The established domain from which one contemplates expansion. Vision meeting practical consideration. Partnership in enterprise. Choice between safety and adventure. Authority consolidating, waiting for the right moment to move forward.
meaningRev: Plans thwarted by fear or disrupted by poor judgment. Vision without action, or action without vision. Partnerships souring. Expansion blocked or rushed unwisely. The view from the heights showing problems not solutions. Authority undermined. Choice paralysis or impulsive decision made badly.
description: A tall man looks from a battlemented roof over sea and shore; he holds a globe in his right hand, while a staff in his left rests on the battlement; another is fixed in a ring. The Rose and Cross and Lily should be noticed on the left side.

name: Three of Wands
meaningUp: Expansion, foresight, ships coming in. Efforts beginning to bear fruit. Trade, commerce, collaboration succeeding. The elevated perspective that sees opportunities. Leadership established, ventures underway. Planning proving sound.
meaningRev: Returns delayed or lost entirely. Ventures failing, ships not arriving. Vision proving faulty. Expansion thwarted by obstacles not foreseen. Collaboration breaking down. Good plans undermined by poor execution or bad timing. The horizon empty of promise.
description: A calm, stately personage, with his back turned, looking from a cliff's edge at ships passing over the sea. Three staves are planted in the ground, and he leans slightly on one of them.

name: Four of Wands
meaningUp: Celebration, harmony, homecoming, completion of first stage. The harvest home, prosperity in domestic sphere. Stability, peace, refuge. Successful foundation laid for greater things. Joy shared with community. Rites of passage, weddings, joyful gatherings.
meaningRev: Celebration thwarted or proving hollow. Harmony disrupted, homecoming delayed. The foundation unstable though it appeared solid. Community fractured. Joy forced or short-lived. Transition not properly honored. Success in outer world masking discord in home and heart.
description: From the four great staves planted in the foreground there is a great garland suspended; two female figures uplift nosegays; at their side is a bridge over a moat, leading to an old manorial house.

name: Five of Wands
meaningUp: Competition, conflict, struggle for dominance. The mimic warfare that tests strength without deadly intent. Rivalry, passionate disagreement, chaotic energy seeking direction. The struggle that strengthens, opposition that clarifies purpose. Battles in business and personal arena.
meaningRev: Conflict avoided when it's needed for growth, or conflict becoming genuinely destructive. Competition turning vicious or giving up without trying. Struggle exhausting rather than strengthening. The battle royal becoming mere quarreling. Energy scattered completely, or opposition crushing rather than clarifying. Peace at too high a price.
description: A posse of youths, who are brandishing staves, as if in sport or strife. It is mimic warfare, and hereto correspond the

name: Six of Wands
meaningUp: Victory, recognition, public acclaim. The laurel crown, triumph announced. Leadership acknowledged. Success meeting expectation. Good news arriving, especially regarding reputation or status. The hero's return. Confidence well-founded.
meaningRev: Victory thwarted at the moment of triumph, or success that breeds arrogance. Recognition denied or proving empty. Leadership challenged or corrupted by acclaim. Good news delayed or exposed as false. Pride before the fall. The victory lap becoming a walk of shame. Public acclaim masking private failure.
description: A laurelled horseman bears one staff adorned with a laurel crown; footmen with staves are at his side.

name: Seven of Wands
meaningUp: Defense of position, standing your ground against opposition. Courage to maintain conviction against the many. The high ground held despite assault. Testing of resolve. Fighting for what you've earned. Determined resistance to pressure.
meaningRev: Position overwhelmed or abandoned unnecessarily. Courage failing when most needed. The high ground surrendered or proving indefensible. Resolve crumbling under pressure. Fighting battles not worth winning or giving up battles worth fighting. Defensive stance becoming paranoia, or boundaries collapsed entirely.
description: A young man on a craggy eminence brandishing a staff; six other staves are raised towards him from below.

name: Eight of Wands
meaningUp: Swift action, rapid movement, things falling into place quickly. Messages, travel, sudden progress. The arrows flying straight to their target. Events accelerating. Communication flowing. The path clear and the goal in sight.
meaningRev: Momentum thwarted, messages delayed or miscommunicated. Travel plans disrupted. The swift progress grinding to halt. Arrows falling short or flying wild. Timing off, the path suddenly blocked. Communication breakdown. Haste making waste, or necessary speed impossible to achieve.
description: The card represents motion through the immovable-a flight of wands through an open country; but they draw to the term of their course. That which they signify is at hand; it may be even on the threshold.

name: Nine of Wands
meaningUp: Perseverance, wounded but not beaten, defensive strength. The last stand, gathering strength for final push. Lessons learned from past battles. Wary but not defeated. Stamina and resilience. The guardian who remains at post despite exhaustion.
meaningRev: Perseverance becoming obsession with lost causes, or giving up when victory is near. Wounds preventing further action, or wounds unhealed causing poor judgment. Defensiveness becoming paranoia. Past battles haunting present. Exhaustion winning over determination. The final stand becoming collapse, or unnecessary struggle from not knowing when to quit.
description: The figure leans upon his staff and has an expectant look, as if awaiting an enemy. Behind are eight other staves--erect, in orderly disposition, like a palisade.

name: Ten of Wands
meaningUp: Burden, responsibility, carrying heavy load. Success that becomes oppressive. All the duties and obligations of achievement. Hard work near completion but still requiring great effort. Responsibility shouldered alone. The weight of the world on one's shoulders, but still moving forward.
meaningRev: Burden dropped, either through collapse or liberation. Responsibility thwarted by inability to carry on, or responsibility abandoned. The heavy load proving too much, or discovered to be unnecessary. Delegation finally learned, or help refused when needed. Success poisoned by its costs, or burdens shared bringing relief.
description: A man oppressed by the weight of the ten staves which he is carrying.

name: Page of Cups
meaningUp: Emotional openness, intuition, creative beginnings, sensitivity, romantic messages. The cup lifted to receive. Studious nature, willingness to learn of the heart. News of love or creative opportunity. Gentle disposition. Artistic inclinations emerging.
meaningRev: Emotional openness becoming vulnerability to manipulation, or sensitivity thwarted by cynicism. Intuition ignored or leading astray. Creative beginnings that don't develop. Messages of love proving false or not arriving. The willing student unable to learn. Emotional immaturity causing problems or sweet nature exploited.
description: A fair, pleasing, somewhat effeminate page, of studious and intent aspect, contemplates a fish rising from a cup to look at him. It is the pictures of the mind taking form.

name: Knight of Cups
meaningUp: Romance, charm, imagination, emotional idealism. The proposal, invitation, opportunity in matters of heart. Artistic nature, the dreamer who pursues dreams. Emotional courage, following the heart. The lover, the poet, the visionary.
meaningRev: Romance proving false or thwarted by reality. Charm becoming manipulation. Imagination disconnected from truth. Emotional idealism leading to poor judgment. The proposal declined or proving hollow. Moodiness, fickleness. The dreamer who never awakens or the dream shattered by harsh truth. Emotional cowardice masked as sensitivity.
description: Graceful, but not warlike; riding quietly, wearing a winged helmet, referring to those higher graces of the imagination which sometimes characterize this card. He too is a dreamer, but the images of the side of sense haunt him in his vision.

name: Queen of Cups
meaningUp: Emotional intelligence, intuition, compassion, nurturing. The perfect spouse, loving mother. Psychic sensitivity, deep feeling. Trustworthy counsel, empathetic listening. Creative inspiration through emotional depth. Wisdom of the heart. Flowing with emotional currents while maintaining center.
meaningRev: Emotional intelligence becoming manipulation, or intuition thwarted by emotional turbulence. Compassion enabling dysfunction. Nurturing becoming smothering. Psychic sensitivity overwhelming. The loving mother as controlling mother. Boundaries dissolved inappropriately. Emotional wisdom lost to emotional chaos. The trusted counselor proving untrustworthy.
description: Beautiful, fair, dreamy--as one who sees visions in a cup. This is, however, only one of her aspects; she sees, but she also acts, and her activity feeds her dream.

name: King of Cups
meaningUp: Emotional maturity, balance between head and heart, wise counsel. Creative intelligence, art and science harmonized. Responsible care for others. Fair judgment tempered with compassion. Mastery of emotional realm without being ruled by emotions. The father who feels deeply but acts wisely.
meaningRev: Emotional maturity failing or corrupted. Balance lost, either cold calculation or overwhelmed by feeling. Wise counsel becoming manipulation. Responsibility abandoned or misused. Judgment without compassion or compassion without judgment. Mastery of emotion becoming repression or being mastered by emotion. The father figure emotionally distant or dangerously volatile.
description: He holds a short sceptre in his left hand and a great cup in his right; his throne is set upon the sea; on one side a ship is riding and on the other a dolphin is leaping. The implicit is that the Sign of the Cup naturally refers to water, which appears in all the court cards.

name: Ace of Cups
meaningUp: New love, emotional awakening, spiritual abundance. The overflowing cup, grace descending. Joy, contentment, fertility of heart. The beginning of deep feeling. Divine love made manifest. The chalice offered.
meaningRev: Love thwarted or turned sour. Emotional abundance becoming overwhelming flood or drying to drought. Spiritual connection lost. Joy poisoned. The overflowing cup spilled or the empty cup remaining empty. Grace offered but refused. New relationships proving false or failing to develop.
description: The waters are beneath, and thereon are water-lilies; the hand issues from the cloud, holding in its palm the cup, from which four streams are pouring; a dove, bearing in its bill a cross-marked Host, descriptionends to place the Wafer in the Cup; the dew of water is falling on all sides. It is an intimation of that which may lie behind the Lesser Arcana.

name: Two of Cups
meaningUp: Partnership, love, union, attraction. Mutual respect and affection. Balance in relationship. The alchemical marriage. Soul recognition. Harmony between two people. Desire sanctified through connection.
meaningRev: Partnership dissolving or poisoned by jealousy. Love thwarted by circumstance or corrupted by possession. Union proving false. Attraction becoming obsession or fading entirely. Balance lost in relationship. Harmony becoming discord. The sacred connection profaned or never truly formed.
description: A youth and maiden are pledging one another, and above their cups rises the Caduceus of Hermes, between the great wings of which there appears a lion's head. It is a variant of a sign which is found in a few old examples of this card. Some curious emblematical meanings are attached to it, but they do not concern us in this place.

name: Three of Cups
meaningUp: Celebration, friendship, community, abundance of joy. Shared happiness multiplied. Creative collaboration. Healing through connection. The harvest of relationship. Weddings, births, gatherings of the heart.
meaningRev: Celebration thwarted or revealing emptiness. Friendship betrayed or dependent on superficiality. Community excluding rather than including. Joy not shared or shared in excess leading to harm. Collaboration failing. The gathering that creates hangovers of regret rather than memories of joy. Triangulation and jealousy within groups.
description: Maidens in a garden-ground with cups uplifted, as if pledging one another.

name: Four of Cups
meaningUp: Contemplation, apathy, reevaluation, meditation on what's offered versus what's desired. The pause to consider, feeling of "is this all there is?" Emotional retreat. Not yet seeing the gift being offered. Necessary withdrawal from emotional engagement.
meaningRev: Contemplation becoming depression, or breakthrough from apathy. The offered cup finally seen and accepted, or all cups rejected in bitterness. Meditation revealing truth or leading deeper into illusion. Emotional retreat becoming isolation. The gift recognized too late or sudden awakening to previously unappreciated blessings. Renewed engagement or complete withdrawal.
description: A young man is seated under a tree and contemplates three cups set on the grass before him; an arm issuing from a cloud offers him another cup. His expression notwithstanding is one of discontent with his environment.

name: Five of Cups
meaningUp: Loss, grief, regret, disappointment. Focus on what's gone rather than what remains. Mourning what could have been. The spilled cups capturing all attention while full cups go unnoticed. Necessary sadness, appropriate grief. Emotional reckoning.
meaningRev: Grief thwarted, unable to properly mourn, or recovery beginning. Regret becoming obsessive or finally released. The head lifting to see what still stands. Moving forward or remaining frozen in past. Loss denied its due weight or given more weight than deserved. The partial inheritance accepted or rejected entirely.
description: A dark, cloaked figure, looking sideways at three prone cups two others stand upright behind him; a bridge is in the background, leading to a small keep or holding. Divanatory Meanings: It is a card of loss, but something remains over; three have been taken, but two are left; it is a card of inheritance, patrimony, transmission, but not corresponding to expectations; with some interpreters it is a card of marriage, but not without bitterness or frustration. Reversed: News, alliances, affinity, consanguinity, ancestry, return, false projects

name: Six of Cups
meaningUp: Nostalgia, childhood memories, innocence, reunion. The past as source of joy and learning. Gifts given freely. Simple pleasures. Old friends reconnecting. Childlike wonder reclaimed. The good memories that sustain.
meaningRev: Nostalgia becoming trap in the past, or past wounds preventing present joy. Childhood memories painful rather than sweet. Innocence lost and mourned rather than integrated. Reunion proving awkward or impossible. Living in past glories rather than present reality. The childhood that wasn't childhood. Gifts with unspoken obligations.
description: Children in an old garden, their cups filled with flowers.

name: Seven of Cups
meaningUp: Fantasy, illusion, many options, imagination, wishful thinking. The visions in the cups both alluring and confusing. Dreams and delusions mixed together. Unlimited potential or scattered desire. Creative visualization or escapism.
meaningRev: Illusions cleared or deepening into madness. Fantasy recognized as such or completely overtaking reality. Choice made from many options or paralyzed by too many. Imagination serving practical ends or leading completely astray. Wishful thinking abandoned for reality or hardened into delusion. The dreams revealed as achievable or impossible.
description: Strange chalices of vision, but the images are more especially those of the fantastic spirit.

name: Eight of Cups
meaningUp: Abandonment of the material for the spiritual, walking away from situations that no longer serve. Disappointment leading to quest for deeper meaning. Leaving behind success that feels hollow. The search for authentic fulfillment. Voluntary retreat, pilgrimage.
meaningRev: The leaving thwarted by fear or attachment, or abandonment that's actually running away. The quest for meaning becoming aimless wandering. Walking away from what should be worked through. Spiritual seeking as escapism. Return to what was left, either in wisdom or defeat. The cups abandoned needlessly or clung to desperately.
description: A man of dejected aspect is deserting the cups of his felicity, enterprise, undertaking or previous concern.

name: Nine of Cups
meaningUp: Contentment, satisfaction, wish fulfilled, emotional and material well-being. The wish granted. Pleasure, luxury, comfort deserved. Pride in achievement. The full cup savored. Success in matters of heart.
meaningRev: Satisfaction proving hollow or thwarted by inability to enjoy it. Wishes granted bringing unexpected problems. Pleasure turning to excess. Comfort becoming complacency. Success in material realm masking emotional emptiness. The full cup tasting bitter. Contentment disrupted by discovering wants aren't satisfied after all.
description: A goodly personage has feasted to his heart's content, and abundant refreshment of wine is on the arched counter behind him, seeming to indicate that the future is also assured. The picture offers the material side only, but there are other aspects.

name: Ten of Cups
meaningUp: Emotional fulfillment, family harmony, domestic bliss, lasting happiness. The rainbow blessing over home and heart. Love multiplied through family bonds. Community and belonging. The perfection of emotional life. Peace, joy, and love made manifest in daily life.
meaningRev: Family harmony disrupted or revealed as facade. Domestic bliss thwarted by conflict or external forces. Lasting happiness proving temporary. The rainbow promise unfulfilled. Love within family turned toxic. Community rejection. The perfect picture hiding dysfunction. Emotional fulfillment sought in wrong places or right places but still elusive.
description: Appearance of Cups in a rainbow; it is contemplated in wonder and ecstacy by a man and woman below, evidently husband and wife. His right arm is about her; his left is raised upward; she raises her right arm. The two children dancing near them have not observed the prodigy but are happy after their own manner. There is a home-scene beyond.

name: Page of Pentacles
meaningUp: Opportunity, new beginning in material realm, studiousness, planning, potential for prosperity. The student of practical arts. News regarding money or work. Ambition forming. Dedication to learning manifesting skills. The seed planter.
meaningRev: Opportunity missed or proving false. New beginning thwarted. Studiousness not translating to skill. Planning without execution. Potential for prosperity unrealized. Bad news regarding finances. Ambition without discipline. The seed planted in poor soil or not planted at all. Learning not applied.
description: A youthful figure, looking intently at the pentacle which hovers over his raised hands. He moves slowly, insensible of that which is about him.

name: Knight of Pentacles
meaningUp: Responsibility, routine, reliability, methodical progress. The steady worker. Commitment, persistence, loyalty. Conservative, careful, thorough. Slow but sure. Service given dependably. The plodding horse that reaches destination.
meaningRev: Responsibility becoming boring routine or responsibility shirked. Reliability failing or taken for granted. Methodical progress stopping entirely or revealed as going in circles. Stagnation, laziness, resistance to needed change. Service begrudging. The plodding horse stuck in mud or bolting from harness. Steady becoming stubborn.
description: He rides a slow, enduring, heavy horse, to which his own aspect corresponds. He exhibits his symbol, but does not look therein.

name: Queen of Pentacles
meaningUp: Nurturing abundance, practical care, domestic mastery, resourcefulness, grounded prosperity. Earth mother wisdom. Comfort and security provided. Business acumen combined with generosity. The capable manager of resources and relationships. Practical magic.
meaningRev: Nurturing abundance becoming smothering or withheld. Practical care failing or given resentfully. Domestic mastery undermined by chaos. Resourcefulness turned to manipulation. Prosperity losing ground or achieved through exploitation. The provider unable to provide or providing to control. Security used as weapon.
description: The face suggests that of a dark woman, whose qualities might be summed up in the idea of greatness of soul; she has also the serious cast of intelligence; she contemplates her symbol and may see worlds therein.

name: King of Pentacles
meaningUp: Material mastery, success, leadership in business, generosity from abundance. The established ruler, wise in worldly matters. Reliability, security, wealth shared. Practical intelligence, mathematical gifts realized. Building lasting enterprises. Prosperity with ethics.
meaningRev: Material mastery corrupted or lost. Success poisoned by vice or thwarted by circumstance. Leadership in business becoming exploitation. Generosity withheld or used manipulatively. The established ruler revealed as corrupt or overthrown. Reliability failed. Wealth hoarded. Practical intelligence serving greed. Enterprises crumbling.
description: The figure calls for no special descriptionription the face is rather dark, suggesting also courage, but somewhat lethargic in tendency. The bull's head should be noted as a recurrent symbol on the throne. The sign of this suit is represented throughout as engraved or blazoned with the pentagram, typifying the correspondence of the four elements in human nature and that by which they may be governed. In many old Tarot packs this suit stood for current coin, money, deniers. I have not invented the substitution of pentacles and I have no special cause to sustain in respect of the alternative. But the consensus of divinatory meanings is on the side of some change, because the cards do not happen to deal especially with questions of money.

name: Ace of Pentacles
meaningUp: New financial opportunity, manifestation, prosperity beginning, material gift. The seed of wealth. Practical magic, ideas taking physical form. Security, abundance, tangible success. The offered coin, opportunity in hand.
meaningRev: Opportunity lost or proving false. Manifestation blocked. Prosperity thwarted by poor timing or judgment. Material gift with strings attached or not arriving. The seed that doesn't sprout. Ideas remaining abstract. Security undermined, abundance withheld. The offered coin revealed as fool's gold.
description: A hand--issuing, as usual, from a cloud--holds up a pentacle.

name: Two of Pentacles
meaningUp: Balance, juggling priorities, adaptability, multitasking. The dance of managing multiple demands. Flexibility in face of change. Harmony through movement. Financial juggling. Time management. Keeping everything in motion.
meaningRev: Balance lost, too many balls dropped. Priorities overwhelming or mismanaged. Adaptability failing under pressure. The juggling act collapsing. Financial instability, mismanagement. Time running out. Flexibility becoming chaos, or rigidity preventing necessary adjustment. The dance becoming stumble.
description: A young man, in the act of dancing, has a pentacle in either hand, and they are joined by that endless cord which is like the number 8 reversed.

name: Three of Pentacles
meaningUp: Collaboration, skill recognized, apprenticeship, quality work, building something lasting. Teamwork succeeding. Craftsmanship honored. Planning meeting execution. Learning from masters. Achievement through combined effort.
